title: Conditions That Look Like Ovarian Cancer
author: Kendall K. Morgan

content: Doctors sometimes think of ovarian cancer as a silent disease. It’s true that it usually doesn't have clear symptoms until it’s already at an advanced stage. But ovarian cancer actually does have symptoms. They include:

The problem is that lots of other less serious conditions have these symptoms , too. To catch ovarian cancer sooner, it may help to know some other conditions that might look like it and when to see a doctor.
bullets: Loss of appetite or feeling full
Peeing often or feeling like you need to

content_blocks.text: Doctors sometimes think of ovarian cancer as a silent disease. It’s true that it usually doesn't have clear symptoms until it’s already at an advanced stage. But ovarian cancer actually does have symptoms. They include:
associated_bullets: Loss of appetite or feeling full
Peeing often or feeling like you need to

content_blocks.text: The problem is that lots of other less serious conditions have these symptoms , too. To catch ovarian cancer sooner, it may help to know some other conditions that might look like it and when to see a doctor.

sections.heading: Ovarian Cancer vs. Ovarian Cysts
content: Ovarian cysts are fluid-filled sacs or pockets of normal tissue, while ovarian cancers are solid masses of cancer cells. Ovarian cysts may have symptoms and can come and go with your menstrual cycle . Sometimes, cysts can cause symptoms similar to those of ovarian cancer , including:
If you’re having these symptoms, a doctor can use ultrasound to look and see if it’s a cyst or a tumor. If it's a cyst, they’ll likely keep an eye on it to make sure it goes away.
bullets: Belly pain that can be sharp

Ovarian cysts may have symptoms and can come and go with your menstrual cycle . Sometimes, cysts can cause symptoms similar to those of ovarian cancer , including:
associated_bullets: Belly pain that can be sharp

content_blocks.text: If you’re having these symptoms, a doctor can use ultrasound to look and see if it’s a cyst or a tumor. If it's a cyst, they’ll likely keep an eye on it to make sure it goes away.

sections.heading: Ovarian Cancer vs. Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
content: You might think ovarian cancer and IBS would look different, but both can cause symptoms including:
If these symptoms are new for you and last for a few weeks, see a doctor. Unlike symptoms of ovarian cancer, symptoms of IBS may be triggered by food or stress .

content_blocks.text: You might think ovarian cancer and IBS would look different, but both can cause symptoms including:
If these symptoms are new for you and last for a few weeks, see a doctor. Unlike symptoms of ovarian cancer, symptoms of IBS may be triggered by food or stress .

sections.heading: Ovarian Cancer vs. Premenstrual Syndrome (PMS)
content: Some of the symptoms of ovarian cancer and PMS overlap. Both can cause:
But PMS often has other changes, including:
While everyone is different, PMS tends to happen in a predictable way. Unlike ovarian cancer, it should come and go with your menstrual cycle.
bullets: Mood changes, including depression , crying, crankiness, or anger

content_blocks.text: Some of the symptoms of ovarian cancer and PMS overlap. Both can cause:
But PMS often has other changes, including:
associated_bullets: Mood changes, including depression , crying, crankiness, or anger

content_blocks.text: While everyone is different, PMS tends to happen in a predictable way. Unlike ovarian cancer, it should come and go with your menstrual cycle.

sections.heading: Ovarian Cancer vs. Endometriosis
content: Endometriosis happens when extra tissue similar to the lining of your uterus grows outside of it. It can cause symptoms similar to those of ovarian cancer and other conditions that look like ovarian cancer, including:

The symptoms of endometriosis usually get worse during your menstrual period. They may also come with heavy periods and infertility . A doctor can do a pelvic exam , ultrasound, and other tests if they think you might have this. People with endometriosis do have more risk for ovarian cancer, but most women with endometriosis don't get ovarian cancer.
bullets: Pain when going to the bathroom

content_blocks.text: Endometriosis happens when extra tissue similar to the lining of your uterus grows outside of it. It can cause symptoms similar to those of ovarian cancer and other conditions that look like ovarian cancer, including:
associated_bullets: Pain when going to the bathroom

sections.heading: Ovarian Cancer vs. Uterine Fibroids
content: Uterine fibroids are growths in the uterus that aren’t cancer. They can feel something like ovarian cancer, with signs and symptoms including:
But uterine fibroids often come with other symptoms, including:
bullets: Peeing a lot or trouble peeing

sections.heading: Ovarian Cancer vs. Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID)
content: Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is caused by an infection. Some symptoms overlap with those of ovarian cancer, including:
But PID often includes other symptoms, such as:
PID is more likely if you've had unprotected sex with multiple partners or have a history of sexually transmitted infections.
bullets: Vaginal discharge with a bad odor

sections.heading: Ovarian Cancer vs. Menstrual Cramps
content: Both ovarian cancer and menstrual cramps can cause belly pain. The pain of menstrual cramps may be:

If your pain is related to menstrual cramps, it should start before your period and last a few days before going away. Sometimes, menstrual cramps are related to other conditions that also can look like ovarian cancer, including:
bullets: Radiating into your lower back or legs

sections.heading: Ovarian Cancer vs. Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs)
content: Urinary tract infections (UTIs) are common in women. You may have a UTI if you notice:
Many of these symptoms can also be a sign of ovarian cancer, although a UTI is more likely. Your doctor can test your urine to see if what you have is a UTI. They usually go away with antibiotics .
bullets: Changes in the way your pee looks or smells

content_blocks.text: Urinary tract infections (UTIs) are common in women. You may have a UTI if you notice:
associated_bullets: Changes in the way your pee looks or smells

content_blocks.text: Many of these symptoms can also be a sign of ovarian cancer, although a UTI is more likely. Your doctor can test your urine to see if what you have is a UTI. They usually go away with antibiotics .

sections.heading: Ovarian Cancer vs. Ectopic Pregnancy
content: An ectopic pregnancy happens when a fertilized egg implants outside the uterus, usually in a fallopian tube. While ovarian cancer symptoms are often subtle, ectopic pregnancies can cause:

A pregnancy test can help to rule out an ectopic pregnancy. But this condition is an emergency and can be life-threatening. If you think you are pregnant and have symptoms of an ectopic pregnancy, see a doctor right away.
bullets: Severe belly or pelvic pain with bleeding

sections.heading: Ovarian Cancer vs. Appendicitis
content: Appendicitis is inflammation of the appendix often caused by an infection. It’s more common in younger people, ages 10 to 30, while ovarian cancer usually happens later in life. Ovarian cancer and appendicitis can both cause belly pain. But the pain of appendicitis is typically:
Appendicitis also can cause:
Appendicitis can cause serious complications, including a life-threatening rupture. If you think you may have appendicitis, see a doctor right away.
bullets: Sudden and severe, beginning on the right side or around the bellybutton and shifting right
Worsening with coughing , walking, or sudden movements

sections.heading: Ovarian Cancer vs. Other Cancers
content: Ovarian cancer can have symptoms similar to those of other cancers in the abdomen . For example, colon cancer symptoms can include:
Another example is peritoneal cancer . This cancer spreads from another organ to the lining of the abdomen. Symptoms may be similar to those of ovarian cancer, including:

sections.heading: When to See a Doctor
content: If you’re having symptoms that might be ovarian cancer and they’re unexplained, new for you, and don't go away in a relatively short period of time, call your doctor. You should take notice also if the symptoms don't respond to over-the-counter medicines or home remedies.

There is no easy way to screen for ovarian cancer, but a doctor can help you rule out other possibilities and get to the bottom of your symptoms. Let your doctor know if you may be at higher risk of ovarian cancer due to your family history or an inherited cancer syndrome. It's important to catch ovarian cancer early, when it’s easier to treat.

sections.heading: When to See a Doctor
content: If you’re having symptoms that might be ovarian cancer and they’re unexplained, new for you, and don't go away in a relatively short period of time, call your doctor. You should take notice also if the symptoms don't respond to over-the-counter medicines or home remedies.

There is no easy way to screen for ovarian cancer, but a doctor can help you rule out other possibilities and get to the bottom of your symptoms. Let your doctor know if you may be at higher risk of ovarian cancer due to your family history or an inherited cancer syndrome. It's important to catch ovarian cancer early, when it’s easier to treat.

Let your doctor know if you may be at higher risk of ovarian cancer due to your family history or an inherited cancer syndrome. It's important to catch ovarian cancer early, when it’s easier to treat.

Rush University Medical Center: “5 Early Signs of Ovarian Cancer.”
CDC: "Ovarian Cancer: What Should I Know about Screening?"
meta_description: Many conditions have symptoms similar to those of ovarian cancer. Find out what to watch for and when to see a doctor.
